entry.title: Re: PO delivery time with icoterm
entry.content:
Hi , 

I understand your point. 

There is no separate transit time (from vendor to your plant). Assuming the planned lead time includes shipping time by the vendor in other INCO term cases, here in your case there is no shipping time. Technically, you are taking ownership of goods at vendor's location and hence your GR processing time starts here. 

If you do not want to do above, some organizations do not really post GR at this point of time and use 2 work arounds :

1. Use 103 (receipt at vendor) & 101 (receipt at plant) movement types

2. Use Inbound Delivery (receipt at vendor) & 101 (receipt at plant 

In both the above cases, you need to include transit time in planned dely time. 

If you want to report transit time, you need to develop a report depending on which work around you used. 

Best regards, Ramki

entry.title: Re: MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM - doesnt work - SAP Public C...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM does not influence the logic during Purchase Requisition (PR) ‚Üí Purchase Order (PO) conversion.
As a result, the ‚ÄúInfo Record Update‚Äù field remains empty when creating POs from PRs, even though it works correctly for manually created POs.

This is because PR-to-PO processing uses a different business context, and the BAdI you used is not called during this conversion step.

Root Cause

The PR-to-PO process runs in a controlled workflow where MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM is bypassed.
Therefore, any custom logic implemented in this BAdI will not be executed during PR conversion, which is why the Info Record Update flag is not defaulted automatically.

Resolution Overview

To ensure consistent behavior, you need to use the BAdI that is actually triggered for all PO creation modes‚Äîincluding conversions from PRs.

The correct BAdI for this scenario in Public Cloud is:

BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO

This BAdI is executed just before the PO is saved, making it reliable across manual creation, PR conversion, and automated processes.

The issue is caused by using a BAdI that does not participate in the PR-to-PO process.
Switching to BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO provides a reliable, Public Cloud‚Äìcompliant solution that ensures the ‚ÄúInfo Record Update‚Äù field is always set during all types of PO creation.

 

Extensibility for Purchase Order Apps

Best Regards'

Aishwarya

entry.title: Enhancing Standard MDG Search with Custom Fields
entry.content:
üõ†Ô∏è Enhancing Standard MDG Search with Custom Fields

This article is a detailed outline for enhancing the SAP MDG Standard Search with a custom field! This process involves customizing the search view, defining mappings, and adjusting the Web Dynpro configuration.

 Adding the Custom Field : ZZABCD to the search screen for the Supplier Business Partner.

This procedure extends the standard search configuration, likely for Database Search or Enterprise Search, to incorporate your custom attribute, ZZABCD, for the Supplier (Business Partner) entity.

Please follow the below mentioned steps:

Step 1: Configure the Search View in MDG-IMG

  1. Go to transaction code MDGIMG.

 

  1. Navigate to the relevant search configuration path, depending on the MDG version and search type).
  2. Select the Search view configuration, in your case, MDG_BS_SUP_SUPPLIER (or the corresponding entry for your chosen search mode, e.g., HANA, Database, or Enterprise Search).

 

  1. Select Attributes based on entity type.
  2. Locate and select your Custom field ZZABCD to include it in the search attributes.
    • Note on Read-Only: If the field is read-only in the Search View definition, you may need to check the Data Modeling and Structure Generation steps for your custom field. The next step addresses the mapping required for data retrieval.

Step 2: Define Joins and Field Mapping (SMT)

  1. Define Joins and Field Mapping Reuse Tables.
    • This is the crucial step that connects your custom field ZZABCD in the MDG staging structure to the underlying database table where the search view will retrieve the data.
    • This is typically performed using the Search Metadata Tool (SMT) or by maintaining the necessary joins/mapping within the search view definition itself, ensuring the data source for ZZABCD is correctly linked to the search view's data model.

Step 3: Review, Generate, and Configure UI

7. Click on Review and Generate.

    • This action finalizes the search view configuration and generates or updates the underlying search structures and database views (especially critical for HANA Search or Database Search).

8. Go to the transaction code SE80  and  FPM_SEARCH_UIBB  double-click on the configuration BS_SP_DQUERY_HA (or the configuration ID specific to your supplier search screen, often based on Business Partner).

 

    • This opens the Floorplan Manager (FPM) configuration for the Search User Interface Building Block (UIBB). You need to create a Customizing or Enhancement layer here.

9.In the FPM configuration, navigate to the Search Criteria area and use the FPM Configuration Editor to add the Custom field  ZZABCD to the search criteria fields list.

This final configuration step makes the field visible and available as a search parameter for end-users on the MDG search screen.

entry.title: Re: Adding where condition in CDS extension
entry.content:
Good day @dhina_007 

Thank you for your question.

Due to the public cloud clean-core principle, you cannot add a WHERE condition to a standard CDS view when you use CDS extensions. The reason is, adding WHERE changes the released API view and can potentially break dependent applications,  therefore violating the clean-core restrictions.

I recommend you create your own Custom CDS View (or Custom Analytical Query) based on the standard view and apply your required filters there.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Custom CDS Views, Extensibility Enablement, SAP HANA Core Data Services (CDS) Reference,

The Blog: Getting Started with ABAP Core Data Services (CDS)  also provides some good insights. Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Engineering Change Record (ECR) for Inspection Plan -...
entry.content:
Good day @ksnv 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Creating Change Record Types, Creating a Change Record & Manage Change Records

The public cloud, in its out-of-the box standard, currently does not support the inspection plan object type for change records. This restriction is also listed in the 3331841 Note under the limitations for Change Record types.

You can consult Note 3325248 for information on enabling Change Number for Dynamic Field Control in a Change Record.

Since the public cloud restricts the aforementioned point, here is what I suggest on how you can still achieve your goal:

  • Use ECR for supported objects such as Material, BOM and Document.
  • Manage Inspection Plan changes separately through workflow or documented governance
  • If you strictly require auditability, I suggest you build a BTP extension.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Key Mapping in SAP MDG
entry.content:
SAP Master Data Governance 

the management of different number ranges for different target systems in an SAP MDG Hub Deployment is a standard requirement and is primarily achieved using the System-Specific Number Range Definition and the Key Mapping functionality.

The goal is to allow the MDG Hub to create a master data record (e.g., Business Partner/Customer/Supplier) with its own number, while the target systems receive a different, local number upon replication.

Here is the standard Configuration :

 MDG Hub Numbering vs. Target System Numbering

In an MDG Hub deployment, the MDG system assigns the Central Governance ID (the unique master data key) for the record. For replication to a target system with a different number range,

 

  1. MDG Hub: Typically use Internal Number Assignment for the Business Partner (BP) in the MDG system itself. The BP number range is configured in the Hub using transaction SNRO for the object BU_PARTNER.
  2. Target ERP System: The corresponding number range for the Customer/Vendor/Material in the target system must be configured for External Number Assignment. This allows the target system to accept the different number that will be derived during replication.

 

 Configuration for Target System Number Ranges

SAP MDG provides specific Customizing activities to define the number range that should be used by the target system for a replicated record, based on its Account Group or Material Type.

Go the  transaction MDGIMG

 (or SPRO under Master Data Governance ‚Üí Central Governance ‚Üí [MDG for Business Partner / Customer / Supplier]).

  1. Number Range Derivation per Target System

This configuration allows you to override the standard number that would be derived in the target system.

  • For Customer/Supplier: Use the Customizing activity:
    • Define Number Ranges for [Customer/Supplier] Account Groups per Target System.
    • In this table, you map the Account Group (or Customer/Supplier Account Group) to the Target System (or Logical System) and assign a specific Number Range Key (Group) that the target system must use for that combination.
  1. Replication of the New Number

When the approved Change Request is replicated using the Data Replication Framework (DRF):

  • The replication service reads the configuration defined in Step A.
  • It determines the correct Target System Number Range (Group) based on the target system and the account group of the master data object.
  • The target system's number logic will then apply the external number assignment logic using that configured group/range key.

 

Key Mapping for Synchronization

Key Mapping is essential to ensure that the unique MDG Hub number is correctly linked to the unique number in each target system.

  • Purpose: The Key Mapping Table stores the relationship between the MDG ID and the corresponding local ID in all connected target systems.
  • Configuration: Key Mapping is configured under MDGIMG ‚Üí General Settings ‚Üí Key Mapping ‚Üí Define Key Mapping (or transaction IDMIMG).
  • Usage:
    • When the record is replicated to Target System A, the local number A is generated and stored in the Key Mapping table alongside the MDG Hub ID.
    • When the record is replicated to Target System B, the local number B is generated (based on its number range) and also stored in the Key Mapping table, linked to the same MDG Hub ID.

This ensures that the MDG system can always look up the correct local number to use for updates or lookups in any specific target system.

Hi everyone,

My team is currently working on a student project with the topic:
Mass Sales Order processing and Auto Delivery execution

The main features of the solution include:

  1. Allow users to create sales orders manually or in bulk via Excel upload

  2. User-friendly UI (no need for VA01/VA02/VA03)

  3. Auto-create outbound delivery after order creation

  4. Track end-to-end process: sales order, delivery, goods issue, billing, cancellation

At this stage, I am focusing on Mass Sales Order Creation via Excel Upload.

I‚Äôve prepared an Excel template for the upload, but I‚Äôm currently facing several issues that I‚Äôd love to get your advice on:

Issues I'm facing:

  1. Understanding Excel fields
    I‚Äôm not sure about the meaning and business purpose of all fields in the Excel file ‚Äì especially from a configuration / SD point of view.

  2. Required vs Optional Fields
    I‚Äôm unclear which fields are required, optional, or auto-filled during SO creation. I understand that this depends on configuration (sales doc type, item category, copy control, etc.), but how should I handle this dynamically?

  3. Handling Multiple Price Conditions per Item
    In real business cases, one item may have multiple condition types (e.g., PR00, K007, discounts, etc.). How should I design the Excel input to handle such pricing complexity?

  4. End-to-End Flow for Mass Upload SO Creation
    I‚Äôm still unclear on what a complete backend flow would look like (BAPI? Custom Z-program? IDoc?)
    Are there any SAP-standard programs or existing real-life examples I can refer to?
    Could anyone share a detailed step-by-step flow of what a typical Mass Upload SO program should cover?

Any suggestions, sample flows, or best practices from your real project experience would be a big help.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Provisioning source of a PR created from a service or...
entry.content:
Good day @PASEK 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

Purchase Requisition, Account Assignment in Purchase Requisition,  Read a Purchase Requisition, Operations for Purchase Requisition, Custom Logic

In summary, the public cloud, due to its clean-core principle, does not provide the possibility to create PR from services orders through the enhancement of BAdIs. That means there is no BAdI to help you achieve your goal of changing the provisioning source of a PR requisition you created from a service order.  The provisioning source is determined strictly by the Material Master procurement type and the Service Order Item Category configuration.

If your intention is to automate, you can achieve this by modifying the PR after you have created using BTP and the API_PURCHASEREQ_PROCESS_SRV.

Let me know if you have further questions.



Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue: 0-Stock Materials Are Not Showing in Stock-Mul...
entry.content:
Hello @Ayuwan1212121212 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

The stock reports only display materials that have a physical stock record. The public cloud does not display stocks that have no quantity. There are a few options you can consider.

The simplest is to use Material Document List to show the material even if your stock is zero. As long as it has any movement, it will display it.

Here you can see different document types displayed. Which indicates materials that have been moved.

For option 2, you can also resolve that issue in public cloud by creating a custom CDS view combining Product Master and Materials Stock. This allows you to report on all materials, whether stock exist or not.

Let me know if you have further question on the CDS views creation.



Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Case Management: Case Hierarchy (Main Cases and Sub-Cases)
entry.content:
Introduction:

In modern case management systems, efficient organization of information is essential for delivering fast and accurate resolutions. Businesses today deal with increasingly complex service requests, operational tasks, and customer interactions. To manage this complexity, leading organizations rely on a hierarchical case structure consisting of main cases and sub-cases. This model provides clarity, accountability, and scalability, enabling teams to divide work intelligently without losing the connection to the bigger picture. With a clear case hierarchy, companies can accelerate issue resolution, improve customer satisfaction, and create a more predictable service operation.

Imagine a customer reports a serious issue that touches multiple departments‚Äîsupport needs to investigate, field service must schedule a visit, and billing has to verify an error. Handling everything under one case would quickly become messy. That‚Äôs where case hierarchy shines. A main case captures the overall problem, while sub-cases help each team manage their part of the work independently, yet still stay tied to the larger story.

Configuration:

In SAP Service Cloud v2, Case Hierarchy is offered as a separate feature that customers can enable at the case-type level. It also provides flexibility, allowing configuration changes across different case-type versions. At any given time, only one version of a case type can be active.

1. Open a draft case type version in detail view

 2. In the General tab, activate the Case Hierarchy feature within the Features Settings section. Once enabled, the Case Hierarchy functionality becomes available for that specific case type.

 3. After enabling the feature, a new tab called Relationship Settings becomes available. Navigate to this tab to proceed.

 4. Select a cascade completion mechanism for main and subcases. There are three options available for the completion mechanism. The first is None, where the main case and sub-cases can be completed independently. The second option, Don't allow main case completion until all sub-cases are completed, prevents closure of the main case until its sub-cases are finished. The third option, Complete all sub-cases when the main case is completed, automatically closes all sub-cases when the main case is completed. These options are largely self-explanatory.

5. Select the appropriate options based on your requirements, then click Save to apply the changes.

6. Click Activate to activate the case type.

Case Hierarchy in Action:

Hiring a Candidate in an Enterprise Service Management Scenario: Consider the process of hiring a new candidate‚Äîa common enterprise workflow that requires coordination across several internal departments. Although it begins as a single request, the end-to-end hiring process consists of multiple activities handled by different teams. This makes it an ideal scenario for using Case Hierarchy with a main case and multiple sub-cases.

When a hiring request is submitted, a main case is created to represent the overall process: onboarding a new employee. This main case captures the core details such as candidate information, job role, joining date, and overall status.

However, completing this process requires contributions from multiple departments: 

1. IT Department ‚Äî IT Setup Sub-Case

The IT team needs to prepare all the necessary resources for the new hire. A sub-case is created to handle tasks such as Laptop allocation and configuration, Email account and system access creation, Software license provisioning and Setting up workstation or remote access. This sub-case is managed independently by IT but remains linked to the main hiring case.

2. Finance Department ‚Äî Payroll & Compliance Sub-Case

Finance also plays a crucial role in onboarding. Their sub-case may include: Setting up payroll for the new employee, Assigning cost centers or budgeting codes, Compliance checks for compensation and benefits and Approvals related to financial onboarding. Again, these tasks are handled within the Finance sub-case but contribute to completing the overall hiring process.

3. HR Department ‚Äî HR Onboarding Sub-Case

The HR team completes several onboarding formalities, such as: Gathering and validating documents, Generating the offer letter and appointment contract, Assigning training, onboarding programs, and buddy systems, Ensuring background checks are completed and Capturing employee master data in the HR system. All of these actions are tracked in a dedicated HR sub-case.

Let‚Äôs create a case to demonstrate this scenario.

1. Create a new case with the newly activated case type and open the case in detail view.

2. To create a sub-case, click the Create button and select Sub-Case.

 3. Once the sub-cases are created, review them in the Sub-Cases section under the Related Entities tab. This tab and section are adaptation-relevant, so they must be added to the screen through Adaptation if they are not already visible.

 4. The Sub-Cases section also allows you to link an existing case as a sub-case. Click the Add Subcases button and choose the appropriate case from the value help and click on Apply.

Here, you can enter a search term, press Enter, and then select the desired case from the list.

Alternatively, click the value help icon to open the case list modal and choose the required case.

Click Apply to link the selected case as a sub-case.

It will then be displayed instantly in the related entities sub-cases section.

Use the Full Screen button to enlarge the section for better viewing.

Hover over the case card to reveal the Remove button, then click it to delink the sub-case.

For the current case type version, the completion mechanism ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt allow main case completion until all sub-cases are completed‚Äù is selected. This prevents the main case from being completed until all its sub-cases are resolved. If attempted to complete the main case before completing the sub-cases, a validation message is displayed.

The system will enforce the configured completion mechanism accordingly.

The hierarchy supports only one level, meaning a parent case can have sub-cases, but a sub-case cannot have its own sub-cases.

Summary:

Case Hierarchy in modern case management systems provides a structured way to manage complex processes by linking a main case with one or more sub-cases. This approach enables organizations to break down large tasks into manageable units while maintaining visibility and control over the overall workflow.

Key points:

  • Feature Enablement: In SAP Service Cloud v2, Case Hierarchy is a separate feature that must be enabled at the case-type level and can be configured differently across case-type versions. At any given time, only one version of a case type can be active.

  • Hierarchy Structure: A main case can have multiple sub-cases, but sub-cases cannot have further child cases, supporting a single-level hierarchy.

  • Completion Mechanism: The system supports configurable completion rules, such as allowing independent closure of main and sub-cases, preventing main case completion until sub-cases are finished, or automatically completing all sub-cases when the main case is closed.

  • Operational Flow: Sub-cases can be created directly or linked from existing cases. Departments like HR, IT, Finance, Facilities, Security, and, if relevant, Travel Desk (for relocations) typically manage the sub-cases, each handling specialized tasks while contributing to the main case‚Äôs resolution.

  • Benefits: Case Hierarchy enhances collaboration across departments, ensures accountability, improves tracking, and provides a clear view of progress at both sub-case and main case levels.

In essence, Case Hierarchy simplifies complex business processes by structuring work into related cases, ensuring that each task is efficiently tracked and managed while maintaining alignment with the overall objective.

entry.title: Re: Custom PO Header & Item Text in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi,

  • In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, PO header and item text types are pre-delivered and cannot be extended.

  • The system does not support adding new text types or modifying the standard text schema for purchasing documents.

  • This behavior is system standard for S/4HANA Public Cloud.

  • For additional custom fields, use Custom Fields and Logic app:

    • Create a custom field

    • Assign it to the Purchase Order Header or Item business context

    • Enable it in the UI (Manage Purchase Orders)

    • Include it in output forms if required

  • Custom fields appear as separate fields, not inside the classic ‚ÄúTexts‚Äù tab.

In case your request is critical for your Go Live, please reach out to your assigned Product Expert or Customer Engagement Executive who will help to coordinate your request. SAP offers a recently launched a new opportunity for SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers to submit improvement requests.

2. Register and accept the Terms of Use

3. Choose a session of your interest

4. Create and submit your improvement request

5. Take a look at existing improvement requests and start voting and commenting

 

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Incorrect behavior during White List verification aft...
entry.content:
Hi @Grzegorz7 
This is a common issue when working with SAP S/4HANA and the Polish VAT White List integration Poland requires companies to verify vendor bank accounts against the official VAT White List (run by the Ministry of Finance). When you run F110 (Automatic Payment Run), SAP checks the vendor‚Äôs bank account against the White List. If the bank account is not registered on the White List, SAP raises the error: VAT Payers List (Poland), bank account validation 0001: Does not exist on the White List.

To resolve this please follow doing steps below.
1. Verify Vendor‚Äôs Bank Account
Check with the vendor if the bank account is officially registered on the Polish VAT White List.
Vendors must submit their bank account details to the Polish tax authorities (KAS). If they haven‚Äôt, the account won‚Äôt appear in the list.

2. Update Vendor Master Data in SAP
Go to FK02 (Change Vendor) or BP (Business Partner) transaction. Ensure the correct bank account number (IBAN) is maintained. Double-check formatting (no spaces, correct country code, etc.).

3. Run White List Check Manually
Use transaction FIWTWL (VAT Payers List Check) or the SAP-provided report to test the vendor‚Äôs account against the White List. This helps confirm whether the issue is with SAP data or the official registry.

4. Decide on Payment Handling
If the account is not on the White List then do following options
Option A: Ask the vendor to register the account with the tax authorities.
Option B: Pay to a listed account (if the vendor has multiple).
Option C: Proceed with payment but be aware of tax risk (not recommended).

5. You have to ensure your system is having the SAP Notes mentioned below. SAP has delivered OSS Notes and configuration for Poland VAT White List

  1. SAP Note 2812573 ‚Äì VAT Payers List (Poland) integration. 
  2. SAP Note 2830090 ‚Äì Enhancements for bank account validation

Hope this will resolve your error.

entry.title: Re: Asset sales in Colombia withholding tax
entry.content:
Dear Ramana,
SAP does not currently provide a standard process to directly link sales orders with asset master data for asset retirement in Colombia. The recommended approach is to use SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) for e-invoicing and Extended Withholding Tax functionality for Colombian tax rules. Asset sales should be processed via asset retirement with customer clearing, and the e-invoice submission is handled through DRC. There is no SAP Note that introduces a direct link between sales orders and asset master data; instead, you must configure withholding tax and reporting separately

I can recommend you some of the standard processes which can help you.

Configure Extended Withholding Tax for Colombia in FI (Finance). Define withholding tax types for VAT, income tax, and ICA. Ensure correct base amounts and thresholds are set.

Process asset sales via asset retirement transactions (ABAON/F-92). This ensures the asset is retired in Asset Accounting and revenue is posted in FI/SD. Customer invoice generated here is picked up by DRC.

Integrate with SAP DRC for e-invoicing. Ensure customer invoices from asset retirement flow into DRC.
Submit e-invoices to DIAN as required.

Run statutory reports for VAT withholding and other taxes monthly. Use SAP‚Äôs reporting apps to generate and submit declarations.

Hope this can help you to handle asset sales in Colombia using asset retirement transactions + Extended Withholding Tax + SAP DRC for e-invoicing.

Please confirm if it works with you.

entry.title: Flow Builder Plus: What Usually Stops Cash Flows from Getting Created
entry.content:
If you work with Cash Management in SAP S/4HANA, you‚Äôve probably run into this at least once: a document gets posted, but nothing shows up in FQM_FLOW. Flow Builder Plus runs without errors, yet no cash flows are created. Customers raise cases on this all the time, and the pattern is usually the same.

Here‚Äôs the thing. Flow Builder Plus is reliable, but it‚Äôs strict about the conditions under which it generates flows. Miss one key detail, and the flow quietly disappears somewhere in the pipeline. This post walks through the common reasons why it happens, what they really mean, and how to check them without getting lost in technical rabbit holes.


1. Flow Type Assignment: The First Thing to Check

If Flow Type isn‚Äôt assigned to a line item, Flow Builder Plus simply won‚Äôt pick it up.
Cash flow generation depends entirely on this field.

Only these Flow Type ranges actually create flows in One Exposure:

  • 90* Actual
  • 80* Bank clearing
  • 70* Payment Request clearing
  • 60* Customer/Vendor
  • 50* Others

If your document doesn‚Äôt fall into one of these buckets, Flow Builder Plus ignores it. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important to confirm Flow Type is present in BSEG and correctly categorized. Refer to Flow Types | SAP Help Portal for understanding how Flow Type is updated in BSEG.

If you suspect Flow Types got missed, run the report FQM_UPDATE_FLOW_TYPE to refresh them in BSEG.

Also check whether Flow Types exist in VFCLMFLOWLVL. If not, run FQM_INIT_FLOW_CAT_KF to push the catalog into the system.

2. Line-Item Status: Cleared Items and Zero Amounts

Flow Builder Plus doesn‚Äôt generate flows for cleared items unless the Flow Type is 90*.
So, if BSEG-AUGBL is filled, that line is already settled and becomes irrelevant for most flow types.

Zero amounts are also a blocker. If WRBTR or DMBTR is zero, there‚Äôs no cash-relevant movement to represent, and Flow Builder Plus won‚Äôt create anything.

3. IBU Flows: The Quiet Showstopper

This one catches many users off guard.
If an IBU flow already sits in FQM_FLOW for the same G/L or technical ID and company code, the system won‚Äôt generate another flow for earlier documents.

The key comparison is:

  • IBU flow‚Äôs transaction date in FQM_FLOW
    vs
  • The document‚Äôs posting date and planning date

If the IBU flow‚Äôs transaction date is later, the document gets skipped.
For an IBU flow, the TRANSACTION_OWNER will always be 'IBU'. 

4. Aggregation Effect: Why Everything Drops to Zero After FQM_AGGREGATE_FLOWS

After running FQM_AGGREGATE_FLOWS, some users notice that Flow Builder Plus or Flow Builder Plus 2 suddenly generates zero flows. This is expected behavior in certain cases.

SAP has detailed this in KBA 3679718, but the simple version is: once flows are aggregated, Flow Builder sees no new granular items to generate.

5. Start Date for One Exposure: A Small Setting With a Big Impact

In S/4HANA OP 2023, there‚Äôs a configuration for defining the start date for One Exposure.
If you‚Äôve set a date there, any document prior to that date will not show up in FQM_FLOW.

This setting lives here:
SPRO ‚Üí Financial Supply Chain Management ‚Üí Cash and Liquidity Management ‚Üí Cash Management ‚Üí Data Setup ‚Üí Define Start Date for One Exposure

6. Liquidity Analysis Settings: Conditions That Must Be Met

If your system uses Liquidity Analysis, two checks matter:

  • Cash Scope must be set to Full Scope
  • Business function FIN_FSCM_CLM must be active in SFW5

Without these, Flow Builder Plus can‚Äôt update flows the way Liquidity Analysis expects.
Also make sure the prerequisites in KBA 3444282 are followed so automatic updates to FQM_FLOW actually trigger.

7. Cash Position: Workflow Linkage Matters

For cash position scenarios, automatic flow creation depends on workflow linkage.
Check SWETYPV and activate the linkage as described in KBA 3193587. If this isn‚Äôt active, cash position data never reaches FQM_FLOW.

8. MM Flows: The Usual Points That Get Missed

MM flows have their own pattern of issues. When Flow Builder Plus is run manually and still no MM flows show up, the following are usually the reasons:

  • The MM source application isn‚Äôt active
  • The PO or PR doesn‚Äôt have a vendor/supplier assigned
  • The vendor doesn't have Planning Level and Planning Group

Without those details, Flow Builder Plus has no basis to generate MM-related flows.
Also note that when a PO or PR is created, the entry first goes to FCLM_MM_STAGING. The workflow linkage (KBA 3193587) then moves it into FQM_FLOW. If that linkage isn‚Äôt active, nothing happens downstream.

Closing Thoughts

Most missing-flow issues don‚Äôt require deep debugging. They come down to Flow Type gaps, cleared or zero-amount line items, IBU conflicts, workflow linkage, or Liquidity Analysis settings that aren‚Äôt fully wired.

Once you‚Äôve seen these patterns a few times, you can predict exactly where the break is. And when FQM_FLOW stays empty, working through these areas usually leads you straight to the reason.

entry.title: Leveraging Angular AI Patterns & MCP for Next-Gen SAP Spartacus Storefronts
entry.content:
In the realm of modern commerce architectures, storefront frameworks must be agile, extensible and cloud-ready. The composable storefront paradigm, exemplified by SAP Spartacus relies not just on headless APIs, but also on modular frontend frameworks that can evolve rapidly.
With Angular‚Äôs newly documented AI design patterns and the built-in CLI MCP (Model Context Protocol) server, frontend teams gain powerful tools for building smarter, faster and better-maintained storefronts.

In this article we‚Äôll explore:

  1. What Angular introduces via its AI-/signal-based design patterns

  2. How the MCP server enables AI-assisted development workflows

  3. Why these matter for a Spartacus-based composable storefront

  4. Practical considerations & best practices for enterprise commerce teams

 

Angular‚Äôs AI Design Patterns: What‚Äôs New

Angular‚Äôs ‚ÄúDesign Patterns for AI SDKs & Signals‚Äù doc introduces several key themes:

  • Separating live user input from submission triggers by using signals to control when resource loaders run.

  • Use of resource(...) API for async/streaming workflows (especially useful when interacting with LLMs).

  • Performance and UX implications: streaming, loading states, SSR/hydration, zoneless change detection‚Äîall of these get special treatment.

From a storefront viewpoint: these patterns mean your UI can better handle unpredictable external services (e.g., personalization engines, headless CMS, AI-recommendation APIs) while maintaining performance and resilience.

 

Angular CLI MCP Server: What It Enables

Angular also provides an MCP server embedded in the CLI. Key points from the documentation:

  • The tool allows external AI assistants / development agents to interact with the Angular project via MCP, enabling code generation, project listing, migration assistance, etc.

  • Configuration is straightforward: e.g., create mcp.json in .vscode/ or other IDEs to register the angular-cli server.

  • Supports flags like --read-only, --local-only, and enables both standard and experimental tools (such as modernize, onpush_zoneless_migration).

For storefront projects, this means you can embed AI-driven dev workflows: automating component generation, enforcing best practices, performing migration analysis from legacy modules, and accelerating feature rollout.

 

Why This Matters for SAP Spartacus & Composable Storefronts

Now let‚Äôs tie this back to Spartacus and composable storefront architecture:

  1. Composable storefronts = smaller, faster modules
    Spartacus encourages modular Angular feature libraries (checkout, product-listing, CMS, etc.). By using Angular‚Äôs signal patterns + resource, you can build modules that react more efficiently, load lazily, stream data, and handle slower/cached micro-services gracefully.

  2. Faster developer velocity & consistency
    With MCP server support, teams working on Spartacus can create scaffolding for new features, enforce standard patterns (e.g., using signals, lazy modules, standalone components), and ensure code-style consistency across multiple storefront modules or markets.

  3. Legacy migration readiness
    Many organizations running SAP Commerce still use legacy Accelerators or monolithic storefronts. The onpush_zoneless_migration tool in Angular CLI‚Äôs MCP server becomes a highlight: enabling analysis of old change-detection patterns and preparing for zoneless change detection‚Äîa big win for performance. This aligns with a Spartacus migration path.

  4. AI-powered smart storefronts
    With signals and streaming resource APIs, storefronts can better integrate AI features (recommendations, personalization, chatbots). Spartacus modules can adopt these patterns to build UIs that time-slice interactions, show incremental loading, hydrate smoothly, and degrade gracefully.

Practical Recommendations for Enterprise Commerce Teams

  • Adopt Angular version alignment: Ensure your Spartacus project uses a compatible Angular version that supports signals and resource APIs.

  • Use Angular MCP server for dev workflows: Configure MCP in your IDE to enable team-wide tooling (code gen, analysis, migrations).

  • Modularize Spartacus features: Map your storefront modules (PDP, PLP, Checkout, B2B) into Angular feature libraries. Use signal-based data flows for performance.

  • Plan legacy migration with zoneless in mind: When migrating from an older storefront, use the MCP tool onpush_zoneless_migration to assess and gradually move to zoneless change detection.

  • Leverage AI/design patterns for storefront resilience: For any external API (headless CMS, personalization engine, recommendation services), build UI around resource patterns: loading, retry, streaming, incremental updates.

  • Govern & train the team: Create internal patterns/guides for ‚Äúwhy we use signals‚Äù, ‚Äúhow to use MCP scaffolding‚Äù, ‚Äúhow storefront modules should be structured and delayed loaded‚Äù.

 

Conclusion

The convergence of Angular‚Äôs new AI-centric design patterns and the Angular CLI‚Äôs MCP server opens up rich possibilities for composable storefronts like Spartacus. Enterprises that harness this will enjoy faster development cycles, better UI performance, smoother legacy migrations, and more robust integrations with AI and headless services. If you‚Äôre working with Spartacus, this is an ideal moment to rethink your architecture, your dev-workflow, and your tooling strategy.

entry.title: Les r√¥les essentiels du consultant SAP : un acteur cl√© de la transformation digitale
entry.content:
1. Comprendre les besoins de l‚Äôentreprise

Le r√¥le premier d‚Äôun consultant SAP est l‚Äôanalyse fonctionnelle.
Il doit comprendre les processus m√©tier de l‚Äôentreprise : achats, approvisionnements, finance, logistique, production‚Ä¶
Ensuite, il traduit ces besoins en solutions SAP.

"C‚Äôest le pont entre les √©quipes m√©tier et la technologie".

2. Configurer et personnaliser le syst√®me SAP

Le consultant param√®tre SAP pour qu‚Äôil refl√®te les processus internes de l‚Äôentreprise.
Cela inclut :

la configuration des param√®tres (ex. : types de documents, r√®gles de prix, sch√©mas logistiques) ;

la personnalisation selon les besoins clients ;

l‚Äôoptimisation des flux existants.

 

" Il ne code pas, mais configure le syst√®me pour qu‚Äôil fonctionne comme l‚Äôentreprise le souhaite."

3. Assurer l‚Äôint√©gration entre modules

SAP est un syst√®me modulaire : MM, SD, FI, CO, PP, etc.
Le consultant doit garantir que les flux circulent correctement entre les modules.

Exemple :
Un flux d‚Äôachat en MM doit automatiquement g√©n√©rer des √©critures comptables en FI.

 "Il assure la coh√©rence globale du syst√®me."

4. Tester la solution (cycles de tests)

Avant la mise en production, le consultant :

pr√©pare les sc√©narios de test,

 

ex√©cute les tests unitaires,

accompagne les utilisateurs dans les tests int√©gr√©s (UAT).

"l valide que tout fonctionne correctement"

 

 5. Former les utilisateurs

Un syst√®me SAP bien configur√© n‚Äôa aucune valeur si les utilisateurs ne savent pas l‚Äôutiliser.
Le consultant pr√©pare :

des supports de formation,

des tutoriels,

des sessions de formation pratiques.

"Il aide les √©quipes m√©tier √† devenir autonomes."

 

 6. Support et r√©solution des incidents

Apr√®s le go-live, le consultant continue d'accompagner l‚Äôentreprise :

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H 2025 Release: Smarter Review Flows with New Business Rule Scenario
entry.content:
What‚Äôs New?

SAP SuccessFactors introduces a powerful enhancement via the new feature Business Rules for Performance Management:

New Rule Scenario ‚Äì ‚ÄúChange Field Visibility, Editability, and Required Status on Forms.‚Äù This capability provides administrators with greater control and configurability within Performance Management forms.

Key Highlights

The new functionality allows administrators to define business rules that dynamically modify form fields. Depending on predefined conditions, fields may become visible or hidden, editable or read-only, and required or optional.

Business Use Cases

  • When a manager assigns a rating above or below a given threshold (e.g. Either at higher or at lower end of the rating scale), a justification comment field becomes mandatory prior to submission.
  • When a matrix manager provides an extreme rating, a required checkbox may appear to confirm additional review authorization.

How to Configure

  1. Activate ‚ÄúEnable the latest experience of Performance Management forms‚Äù in the Admin Center.
  2. Enable ‚ÄúBusiness rules for Performance Management.‚Äù
  3. Ensure all relevant fields are correctly configured within the form template.
  4. Create a rule using ‚ÄúChange Field Visibility, Editability, and Required Status on Forms‚Äù in Configure Business Rules.
  5. Assign the rule using Assign Rules to Talent in Admin Tools, with triggers such as Field Change, Form Opening, or Form Saving.

Why It Matters

This important enhancement enables organizations to build smart, dynamic, and condition-based forms that adapt in real time - improving data accuracy, ensuring compliance, and increasing accountability for managers. All of this is achievable without any custom development.

Take Action

Performance reviews should adapt to your business needs. With this new rule scenario, you can make your process intelligent and responsive.

Start configuring today and experience the difference!

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite SAP SuccessFactors HCM Core SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals

entry.title: Re: ADT 3.48 bug - Delete and Ctrl-Z keys are deactivated...
entry.content:
I have created a ticket at SAP Support (note for myself: case 1303039/2025 under my company). They confirmed Nov 14th that the bug was reproduced, and the fix will be part of the 2602 ADT plugin.
The bug is related to the use of the new search dialog.
Until February 2026, there are these workarounds:
  1. Use the old search dialog
  2. If you want to use the new search dialog, press Ctrl+F7 twice each time the bug happens
  3. Use Backspace instead of Delete, right click Undo instead of Ctrl+Z 

 

WORKAROUND 1, as proposed by SAP Support:

  • "You can disable the "new" search dialog in eclipse and get back the old dialog: In the preferences, General > Editors > Text Editors untick the checkbox Use find/replace overlay
    With the old find/replace dialog the issue should not occur."

WORKAROUND 2: the Delete key and Ctrl+Z key come back if you change the current ADT view, for instance by pressing Ctrl+F7 twice.

WORKAROUND 3: you may also use these alternatives:

  • Backspace key instead of Delete
  • Right-Click > Undo instead of Ctrl+Z

entry.title: Re: Shared Object Memory for ABAP for Cloud Development?
entry.content: No, our original Clean Core design attempted to use MQTT messaging + ABAP Class memory. It became clear that architecture is not possible. Our SAPUI5 apps build a queue of updates then process everything in a single ABAP server call.

entry.title: Flexible Quantity of Subscription Billing Items in Solution Orders
entry.content:
When you create a subscription billing item in solution orders, in previous releases of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, when a solution order specialist added a subscription billing item to a solution order, the quantity field was automatically defaulted to `1`.

This system behavior meant that each subscription line item in a solution order could only generate a single follow-up subscription in the SAP Subscription Billing tenant. It's suitable for single-subscription scenarios, but it created a cumbersome and inefficient workflow for end-users needing to sell multiple, identical subscriptions to a single customer.
 
For example, to provide a customer with ten identical software-as-a-service (SaaS) licenses, the end-user was required to create ten separate subscription line items in the solution order. This process was not only repetitive and time-consuming but also increased the risk of data entry errors across the multiple lines.
 
With the 2508 release, this restriction has been lifted. The quantity field for a subscription billing item is now editable, allowing the solution order specialist to specify a quantity greater than one.
 
When a solution order containing a subscription item with a specified quantity (example, quantity of 10) is released, the system will now automatically generate the corresponding number of distinct follow-up subscriptions in the SAP Subscription Billing tenant upon fulfillment.
The quantity determines how many subscriptions the system creates in the SAP Subscription Billing system. If the quantity of the subscription billing item exceeds one, the system creates multiple follow-up subscriptions in the SAP Subscription Billing system after the release of the item. The number of follow-up subscriptions matches the quantity of the subscription billing item in the base unit of measure.

You can find the subscriptions in the transaction history and navigate to the SAP Subscription Billing system for more details.

After you perform a simulation for the subscription billing item, the system calculates the net price for all subscriptions to be created. 

When you create multiple follow-up subscriptions with the status Pending in SAP Subscription Billing and then change the status of any one of these follow-up subscriptions from Pending to Complete, the system updates the status of the subscription billing items to Completed in the solution orders.

Key Aspects:

  • One Line Item, multiple subscriptions: A single solution order line item for a subscription product with a quantity of 'N' will result in 'N' individual, identical subscriptions. 
  • Independent Lifecycle Management: Although generated from a single source item, each of the resulting subscriptions is a separate and distinct subscription. This is a critical point, as it ensures that the lifecycle of each subscription‚Äîincluding renewals, modifications, or cancellations‚Äîcan be managed independently post-creation.

Business Value and Strategic Impact:

This enhancement delivers clear and immediate value by optimizing the order-to-cash process for subscription-based business models.

  1. Process efficiency: The most significant benefit is the reduction in manual effort. Creating one line item with a quantity of 10 is substantially faster and simpler than creating ten individual line items. This frees up your sales and order management teams to focus on more value-added activities.
  2. Reduced error rate: Consolidating multiple subscriptions into a single line item minimizes the potential for inconsistencies and data entry errors that can occur when duplicating lines manually. This leads to cleaner data in both SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP Subscription Billing, reducing billing and reconciliation issues.
  3. Enhanced scalability: For businesses selling subscriptions at scale, this feature is essential. It provides a streamlined and scalable mechanism to handle bulk orders for identical subscriptions, supporting business growth without a linear increase in administrative overhead.
  4. Improved traceability: The solution order maintains a clear record that a single item generated multiple follow-up documents, while the individual subscriptions allow for granular tracking and reporting as needed by the business.

entry.title: Mass inheritance LRP in Functional Location
entry.content:
Hi Experts, I have a custom program uses BAPI to perform mass inheritance - changing the value of Linear Reference Pattern of the child from a parent functional location.

The issue is during the inheritance process, when it detects a new LRPID, SAP triggers a warning message EAML 150: LRP will be changed; there are still documents with LRP XXXX, and this warning message halts the inheritance processing of my custom program and stays at the GUI screen as shown in screenshot, hence none of the child functional location/equipment gets inherited with the new LRP value.

How can I prevent the message from interfering the inheritance process triggered via a custom program?

p.s. I have no other way other than using BAPI to update the technical objects.

entry.title: Re: Simplification List - Asset ACcounting
entry.content:
hello, you can try below steps as first level. 

  1. Use the SAP transaction AFAMA to open and look at the depreciation key settings assigned to your asset. This depreciation key defines how depreciation is calculated, like how many periods to spread it over, and what calculation methods apply.
  2. Check that the number of calculation periods and depreciation areas (different parts of depreciation calculation) in the asset match those defined in the depreciation key. These must line up for the system to calculate depreciation correctly.
  3. View the asset master data in transaction AS03 to see what depreciation areas and calculation periods are set for that specific asset.
  4. Make sure the asset‚Äôs depreciation areas and periods correspond exactly to the depreciation key configuration. If they don‚Äôt match, the system will give errors.
  5. If the depreciation key was updated after the asset was created, you may need to adjust the asset data for alignment. Use AS02 if small changes are required.
  6. Once corrected, run depreciation or a simulation again to verify the error is fixed and depreciation is computed as expected.

entry.title: Re: Pass select-options by reference
entry.content:
Nothing to add to the excellent answer by @holm, except that if you don't need to change the value from your class, you may use IMPORTING instead of CHANGING.

If your question is to define your method parameter as TYPE REF TO the SELECT-OPTIONS field, you may use ASSIGN in the report and pass the field symbol instead of S_TIMPER[]. This solution is less elegant and longer.

Here's the code with the solutions:

DATA time_period TYPE d.

SELECT-OPTIONS s_timper FOR time_period NO-EXTENSION.
PARAMETERS by_chang TYPE string.
PARAMETERS by_impor TYPE string.
PARAMETERS by_refer TYPE string.

CLASS class DEFINITION FINAL
  CREATE PRIVATE.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    TYPES period_range TYPE RANGE OF d.

    DATA ref_period_range TYPE REF TO period_range READ-ONLY.

    CLASS-METHODS by_changing
      CHANGING !period       TYPE period_range
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO class.

    CLASS-METHODS by_importing
      IMPORTING !period       TYPE period_range
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO class.

    CLASS-METHODS by_reference
      IMPORTING !period       TYPE REF TO period_range
      RETURNING VALUE(result) TYPE REF TO class.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS class IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD by_changing.
    result = NEW class( ).
    result->ref_period_range = REF #( period ) ##NEEDED.
    result->ref_period_range->* = VALUE #( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = sy-datum ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD by_importing.
    result = NEW class( ).
    " READ ONLY
    result->ref_period_range = REF #( period ) ##NEEDED.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD by_reference.
    result = NEW class( ).
    result->ref_period_range = period ##NEEDED.
    DATA(lv_date) = VALUE #( result->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ]-low OPTIONAL ).
    result->ref_period_range->* = VALUE #(
        ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = CONV d( lv_date + 1 ) ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

LOAD-OF-PROGRAM.
  DATA(by_changing) = class=>by_changing( CHANGING period = s_timper[] ).

  DATA(by_importing) = class=>by_importing( period = s_timper[] ).

  FIELD-SYMBOLS <ls_timper> TYPE class=>period_range.
  ASSIGN s_timper[] TO <ls_timper>.
  DATA(by_reference) = class=>by_reference( period = REF #( <ls_timper> ) ).

AT SELECTION-SCREEN OUTPUT.
  by_chang = VALUE #( by_changing->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).
  by_impor = VALUE #( by_importing->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).
  by_refer = VALUE #( by_reference->ref_period_range->*[ 1 ] OPTIONAL ).

entry.title: CP/NP don't work for IN with a tables range of type D, T or N
entry.content:
If you run this code with CP, you can see that the date 20250101 doesn't match the ranges table I CP 20250101:

TYPES tr_date TYPE RANGE OF d.
ASSERT abap_false = xsdbool( EXACT d( '20250101' ) IN
                    VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ) ).

Is there any official documentation of this behavior?

NB: I know that I can use the equivalent condition I EQ 20250101, which works as expected, my question is just about the documentation for CP/NP for IN with a tables range of type D or T.

Thank you.

Sandra

ABAP version: 7.52 SP 0. It's probably the same for all ABAP versions.

References to the ABAP Keyword documentation:

  • rel_exp - Tabular Comparison Operator IN | ABAP Keyword Documentation (IN)
  • rel_exp - Comparison Operators for Character-Like Data Types | ABAP Keyword Documentation (CP, NP)

For your information, you may refer to these results below, including EQ, CP, NP and ranges table of type C(8) and C(6) instead of D and T, and also the single operators CP and NP without IN (the test method succeeds):

CLASS test DEFINITION FINAL
  FOR TESTING RISK LEVEL HARMLESS DURATION SHORT.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    METHODS abap_behavior FOR TESTING RAISING cx_static_check.
ENDCLASS.


CLASS test IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD abap_behavior.
    TYPES tr_numc TYPE RANGE OF syspono.
    DATA(lr_numc) = VALUE tr_numc( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '0000000001' ) ).
    DATA(lv_numc) = EXACT syspono( '0000000001' ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_numc IN lr_numc ) ).

    TYPES tv_date_c TYPE c LENGTH 8.
    TYPES tv_time_c TYPE c LENGTH 6.
    TYPES tr_date_c TYPE RANGE OF tv_date_c.
    TYPES tr_time_c TYPE RANGE OF tv_time_c.
    TYPES tr_date   TYPE RANGE OF d.
    TYPES tr_time   TYPE RANGE OF t.
    TYPES tr_dats   TYPE RANGE OF dats.
    TYPES tr_tims   TYPE RANGE OF tims.

    DATA(lv_date) = EXACT d( '20250101' ).
    DATA(lv_time) = EXACT t( '235959' ).

    DATA(lr_date_eq) = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_date_eq_c) = VALUE tr_date_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_dats_eq) = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '20250101' ) ).

    DATA(lr_time_eq) = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_time_eq_c) = VALUE tr_time_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_tims_eq) = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'EQ' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_eq_c ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_eq_c ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_eq ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_eq ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_eq ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_eq ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE D AND T, CP SHOULD BE TRUE BUT ARE FALSE, IS IT DOCUMENTED?
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_cp) = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_dats_cp) = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ).

    DATA(lr_time_cp) = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_tims_cp) = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_cp ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_cp ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE C, CP WORKS
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_cp_c) = VALUE tr_date_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_time_cp_c) = VALUE tr_time_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_cp_c ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_cp_c ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE D AND T, NP SHOULD BE FALSE BUT ARE TRUE, IS IT DOCUMENTED?
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_np) = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_dats_np) = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '20250101' ) ).

    DATA(lr_time_np) = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '235959' ) ).
    DATA(lr_tims_np) = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_np ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_np ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_np ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_np ) ).

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE C, NP WORKS
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA(lr_date_np_c) = VALUE tr_date_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '20250101' ) ).
    DATA(lr_time_np_c) = VALUE tr_time_c( ( sign = 'I' option = 'NP' low = '235959' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_np_c ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_false( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_np_c ) ).

    " NB: WITHOUT RANGES TABLES, CP BEHAVES AS EXPECTED
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time = '235959' ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date = '20250101' ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time CP '2359++' ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date CP '2025*' ) ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

entry.title: Re: CP/NP don't work for IN with a tables range of type D, T or N
entry.content:
I don't have access to ABAP any more  but I guess, the reason is that the behavior of CP after IN is as follows:

 

operand {CP|NP} range_tab-low && range_tab-high

https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abenlogexp_select_option.htm

That means, range_tab-high, containing 00000000 or blanks  in your case, is implicitly concatenated behind range_tab-low and thus the comparison returns false.

entry.title: Is Integration Architecture EA discipline‚Äì or how do we see it?
entry.content:
I did talk on a high-level on integrations and EA in past (my article in SAP EA Community: Enterprise Architecture for integration? ). Recently I‚Äôve also published a Blog in the SAP Community about integrations and EA (Integrations as part of the SAP LeanIX (Enterprise) Architecture?) ‚Äì using SAP LeanIX solutions[1] EAM as a tool of choice. 

It‚Äôs not the first time I talk about integrations, and definitely not the first time I talk about EA‚Ä¶ Somehow, I see some of the statements I made were a bit controversial on the level of EA and TOGAF¬©[2]. 

But why?

Where is Integration Architecture in TOGAF?

‚Ä¶ Of I should not even ask this question?

When we model EA in our EAM solution, where do we place our Integration Architecture? Strictly speaking, if we look at TOGAF there is no Integration Architecture domain ‚Äì it‚Äôs a layer cross all domains ‚Äì it‚Äôs everywhere, right? Or, it‚Äôs only a part of the SBBs? Or some would even say, wait, maybe its part of D. Technology Architecture ‚Äì after all integrations are often observed as ‚Äútechnology‚Äù only‚Ä¶

And this is what I fear ‚Äì if we observe integrations as part of everything, and nothing ‚Äì if we detach integration from strategy (and yes there is Integration Strategy as well) ‚Äì where do we go? If we are only solutioning as per need of Business Processes, or Applications or Data Objects ‚Äì are we in fact consciously pushing integration into silo and ad-hoc solutioning?

Look. we want to apply some Principles in Integration Architecture; like Reuse Policy, Integration Patterns, Integration Use-Cases, Integration Governance etc. How can we build and enforce Integration Strategy, if we are not granted ‚Äúdomain‚Äù (or similar) level?

But, TOGAF is flexible, and nothing is ‚Äúcarved-in-stone‚Äù‚Ä¶ We can tailor TOGAF per our needs‚Ä¶ Is this controversial? Shouldn‚Äôt be.

Integration Service or Interface

What I usually refer as Integration Service, can pretty good match with Interface Fact Sheet in SAP LeanIX[3].

In this respect, Integration Architecture should be observed at the same level as (or as part of) Application and Data Architecture.

  • Application ‚Äúprovides‚Äù and/or ‚Äúconsumes‚Äù.
  • Interface ‚Äútransfers‚Äù Data Object.
  • Interface ‚Äúuses‚Äù IT Component.
  • Initiative ‚Äúaffects‚Äù Interface.

Integration Architecture is the enable for the Business Architecture, just as Technology Architecture is an enabler for the Integration Architecture.

Integration Services are not just dots or lines ‚Äì it‚Äôs much more!, We need to raise the awareness and change the mindset(s) ‚Äì proper integration modeling and design is the key for the success in many initiatives ‚Äì and proper modeling has to come as a result of the Integration Strategy, not just "technical" solutioning on case-to-case basis (silo and ad-hoc).

Let‚Äôs just consider how many projects failed or were delayed because integrations were not properly designed or implemented? And this (usually) has nothing to do with ‚Äúbad‚Äù integration developers and integration engineers‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs (usually) associated with ‚Äúlack‚Äù of Integration Strategy and its governance.

Does this resonate?

Tailoring TOGAF with SAP LeanIX

Yes, I am saying TOGAF, not SAP EAF (Enterprise Architecture Framework)[4], just to be more generalist‚Ä¶ And still, I am here being very pragmatic ‚Äì trying to explain real uses cases ‚Äì putting theoretical framework into practical EAM tool.

Certain mapping is quite obvious, but of course things are not really 1 on 1:

  • B. Business Architecture in TOGAF can easily map with Business Architecture in SAP LeanIX.
  • C. Information System Architecture in TOGAF, can also easily map with Application and Data Architecture in SAP LeanIX
  • D. Technology Architecture in TOGAF seems to be mapping with Technical Architecture in SAP LeamIX.
  • What we see is Strategy & Transformation in SAP LeanIX may be mapped with several phased of TOGAF ADM. I.e. Initiative could probably see somewhere between E. Opportunities and Solution and F. Migration Planning in TOGAF.

But this is only at a high level. Let us be absolutely clear ‚Äì SAP LeanIX does not produce TOGAF style of artifacts. I wouldn‚Äôt say this is because SAP LeanIX is intended to be used only with SAP EAF ‚Äì I see SAP LeanIX as EAM tool, which is not bounded with only one specific EA framework‚Ä¶ Now, none of this is a problem at all, framework is a framework ‚Äì not a rule book, and then again EAM is just a tool, and each tool has its specifics.

Final thoughts

I‚Äôve already given credit to Integration Services in many articles; I‚Äôve already shared my thoughts about importance of proper modeling of the Integration Services ‚Äì and I‚Äôve also shared my thoughts that Integration Architecture should also be recognized on the level of EA.

Of course, those are only my thoughts... 

Check out my other articles (in SAP Community)  and all other articles in SAP Community and SAP EA Community

References

[1] SAP LeanIX: https://www.leanix.net/en/

[2] TOGAF: https://www.opengroup.org/togaf

[3] SAP LeanIX Modeling Guidelines: https://help.sap.com/docs/leanix/ea/fact-sheet-modeling-guidelines

[4] SAP EAF: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-architecture-blog-posts/sap-enterprise-architecture-framework/ba-p/124037

entry.title: Re: CP/NP don't work for IN with a tables range of type D or T
entry.content:
Oooooooooooh, thank you very much, that must be the documentation I was looking for! You're right, it works exactly how it is described. If I force the HIGH field to spaces, it works as expected (see code below).

If I may ask, any idea what's behind the use of HIGH for CP and NP?

Demonstration with HIGH date = forced to spaces:

    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    " WITH RANGES TABLE OF TYPE D AND T, HIGH must be set to all spaces to make CP and NP work.
    " !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    DATA lv_date_as_spaces TYPE d.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS <lv_date_as_spaces> TYPE c.
    ASSIGN lv_date_as_spaces TO <lv_date_as_spaces> CASTING.
    <lv_date_as_spaces> = ''.
    lr_date_cp = VALUE tr_date( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' high = lv_date_as_spaces ) ).
    lr_dats_cp = VALUE tr_dats( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '20250101' high = lv_date_as_spaces ) ).

    DATA lv_time_as_spaces TYPE t.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS <lv_time_as_spaces> TYPE c.
    ASSIGN lv_time_as_spaces TO <lv_time_as_spaces> CASTING.
    <lv_time_as_spaces> = ''.
    lr_time_cp = VALUE tr_time( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' high = lv_time_as_spaces ) ).
    lr_tims_cp = VALUE tr_tims( ( sign = 'I' option = 'CP' low = '235959' high = lv_time_as_spaces ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_date_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_time_cp ) ).

    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_date IN lr_dats_cp ) ).
    cl_abap_unit_assert=>assert_true( xsdbool( lv_time IN lr_tims_cp ) ).

Edit: consequently, CP/NP don't work with the N type too.

entry.title: Unit price of by-product generated by Order Split is different with calculation
entry.content:
Dear experts ,

We have some split production orders , but we don't understand how the standard cost of by-product was calculated when we do the order split. 

We read the article in SAP document :  Cost Distribution in the Case of Order Split | SAP Help Portal

but looks like the result in our system is different ! 

Here are my 3 questions :

  1. I'm able to split the parent order just after I release it , without any goods issue to it or any confirmation . Then if I split it , system will receive the by-product with the movement type 531 .
    This looks like : I didn't consume anything , then I got the by-product from nothing !!!  Is this normal in order split process ?

  2. The amount of by-product is a little different with my calculation based on the SAP document above , what caused the difference ? 
    ( in our actual production order , the unit price of by-product is over 10000 JPY more than our calculation !! )

  3. We split the parent order 2 times , 1st time is in September , 2nd time is in October , but the unit price of by-product amount is different between them ! what caused the difference ?

Could anyone help us to understand what is going on in our order split ? 

Thank you very much and best regards,

Shi Zhekui
